diagnoses.explanation: This autoimmune disease can cause a wide range of symptoms, including muscle pain, anemia, and miscarriages. Nervous system involvement might explain pseudoseizures, and gastroparesis could occur due to autonomic dysfunction.

This disorder is characterized by the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies that can lead to blood clots, miscarriages, and may be associated with conditions causing anemia. It is also found in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus, suggesting a potential overlap of symptoms.

Poorly controlled diabetes can lead to gastroparesis due to autonomic neuropathy, muscle pain due to diabetic myonecrosis or neuropathy, and anemia. While it doesn’t directly cause miscarriages, poor glycemic control increases the risk of complications during pregnancy.

A chronic autoimmune disease of the central nervous system, which can present with muscle pain and anemia. Pseudoseizures and gastroparesis could occur due to lesions in areas controlling autonomic functions.

This is an autoimmune disorder that affects neuromuscular transmission, potentially leading to muscle pain and gastroparesis due to involvement of the muscles controlling gastrointestinal movement. It is indirectly associated with anemia and miscarriage through its impact on overall health.

A group of disorders affecting connective tissues, which can lead to gastroparesis due to digestive tract issues, muscle pain, and higher risk of miscarriage. Some types may have vascular involvement that could potentially lead to anemia.

This inflammatory disease can affect multiple organs, including the muscle and central nervous system, potential leading to muscle pain and pseudoseizures. While less common, gastroparesis and anemia could be part of its wide range of symptoms.

Characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain, it also often coexists with other conditions that could explain some of the other symptoms like anemia (due to associated fatigue syndrome). However, it is less directly associated with gastroparesis and miscarriage.

This syndrome is marked by extreme fatigue that doesn't improve with rest and could be associated with muscle pain, an inability to recover normal function, and possibly linked with immune system issues that could indirectly lead to anemia. The connection to gastroparesis and miscarriage is less clear but could be part of a broader dysautonomia.

While primarily an outcome rather than a cause, severe iron-deficiency anemia could exacerbate muscle pain, lead to complications in pregnancy resulting in miscarriage, and contribute to overall poor health status that might align with symptoms like pseudoseizures through its effects on neurocognitive function. However, it would not directly cause gastroparesis.

diagnoses: Osteopenia related to vitamin D deficiency
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease or Ulcerative colitis)
Eating disorders (Anorexia nervosa or Bulimia nervosa)
Psychiatric disorders causing somatic symptoms (e.g., anxiety with somatization)
Infection (viral, bacterial, or fungal leading to lymphadenitis)
Thyroid Disorders (Hyperthyroidism/Hypothyroidism causing concentration issues and possibly hyperglycemia)

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.reason: Direct match with patient's symptom, may contribute to blood viscosity and complications related.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.reason: Could explain post-nasal drip and ulcers due to acid reflux.

diagnoses.name: Peptic Ulcer Disease
diagnoses.reason: Directly matches with the symptom of ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Overlap in symptomatology with POTS; fatigue and other symptoms might correlate.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.reason: Association with POTS and chronic pain, including back pain.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.reason: Could explain chronic back pain and related systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Ankylosing Spondylitis
diagnoses.reason: A specific cause of chronic back pain, systemic involvement possible.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Sinusitis
diagnoses.reason: Could be the cause of post-nasal drip.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Polycythemia
diagnoses.reason: Different etiology than Polycythemia Vera, but possible if due to chronic hypoxia from another condition.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder that increases the risk of blood clots. It can lead to thrombocytopenia, thromboembolic disease, and may indirectly influence healing processes.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. It can cause thrombocytopenia, and its associated inflammation can lead to conditions like pneumonia.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and mouth. It may also lead to systemic symptoms, including joint pain and inflammation that could result in poor healing and increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Immune Thrombocytopenia (ITP)
diagnoses.description: A bleeding disorder in which the immune system attacks and destroys platelets, which are necessary for blood clotting. This condition leads to thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow. It can cause thrombocytopenia and increase the risk of infections like pneumonia.

diagnoses.name: Wegener's Granulomatosis (Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
diagnoses.description: An uncommon disorder that causes inflammation of the blood vessels, which can restrict blood flow to various organs. This may result in a range of symptoms including those relating to the eye and respiratory system.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body. Symptoms may include irritated eyes, sores in the mouth and on the skin, and more serious symptoms such as thrombosis.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: The virus and its more advanced stage, which can weaken the immune system, leading to severe infections like pneumonia, and affecting the body's ability to heal.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder where the body makes antibodies that mistakenly attack and destroy red blood cells, platelets, and sometimes white blood cells. It leads to symptoms like thrombocytopenia and can complicate healing processes.

diagnoses.name: Mycoplasma Pneumoniae Infection
diagnoses.description: A type of bacterial pneumonia that can present with a wide range of symptoms, including respiratory symptoms and general discomfort. In systemic cases, it may cause or aggravate conditions such as thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Head and Neck

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Increased appetite and susceptibility to infection are common symptoms. While dysmenorrhea is not directly linked, diabetes can impact overall health.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: Increased appetite, difficulty focusing vision, and sweats are symptoms. Dysmenorrhea may also be affected due to hormonal imbalances.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Susceptibility to infection and sweats. Dysmenorrhea and difficulty focusing can be part of broader symptomatology.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.reasoning: Increased susceptibility to infection, difficulty focusing, and dysmenorrhea due to iron deficiency can occur.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: Increased susceptibility to infection is a key symptom. Other symptoms could be indirectly related due to overall health deterioration.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Sweats and increased susceptibility to infection are hallmark symptoms. Other symptoms can be indirectly affected.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.reasoning: Dysmenorrhea and an increased appetite are symptoms. Other symptoms like difficulty focusing could correlate with related hormonal imbalances.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune diseases (e.g., Lupus)
diagnoses.reasoning: Increased susceptibility to infection and dysmenorrhea. Difficulty focusing and sweats could be related to systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.reasoning: Increases in appetite and difficulty focusing, with dysmenorrhea potentially worsening due to overall health neglect or stress.

diagnoses.name: Thyroiditis
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause symptoms of both hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism including increased appetite, sweats, and difficulty focusing. Dysmenorrhea may be related to hormonal imbalances.

diagnoses: Chronic Ear Infections (related to Otis Externa)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause dysgeusia, alopecia, and various neurological and dermatological symptoms, though rare, it might explain some of the symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by dry mouth and dysgeusia, along with other systemic symptoms including neurological manifestations that could mimic pseudoseizures.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system) that can present with dysgeusia and neurological symptoms that may resemble pseudoseizures. Alopecia is less commonly associated but can occur.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: While primarily affecting the joints, it can have systemic manifestations including migratory edema and - rarely - alopecia. Neurological manifestations are less direct but can be secondary to medications or vasculitis.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Can lead to alopecia, edema, and in severe cases, myxedema, which can affect cognitive function. Dysgeusia is a less common symptom.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: A tick-borne illness that can cause a wide variety of symptoms, including neurological disorders (potentially pseudoseizures), alopecia, and migratory edema.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that often affects the lungs and lymph glands but can have neurological manifestations and cause dysgeusia, with alopecia being a less common symptom.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing chronic inflammation in blood vessels throughout your body, which can lead to symptoms like mouth sores (which might be interpreted as dysgeusia), and possibly neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: Can cause dysgeusia and alopecia. Typically does not cause pseudoseizures directly but can contribute to overall fatigue and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause a wide range of symptoms depending on the vessels affected, including alopecia, dysgeusia through sensory involvement, and potentially neurological symptoms.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Autoimmune Diseases (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, Rheumatoid Arthritis)
Diabetes Mellitus Type 1 or 2 with complications
Autoimmune Disorders (Systemic lupus erythematosus, Sjögren's syndrome, etc.)
Infections (Bacterial, Viral, or Fungal causing lymphadenitis)
Neuroendocrine Tumors (leading to carcinoid syndrome and hyperglycemia)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) with esophageal eosinophilia

diagnoses.name: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by the narrowing of the coronary arteries due to atherosclerosis, leading to reduced blood flow to the heart. This could manifest as chest pain and is associated with conditions like hyperactivity due to stress or secondary manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Acute Myocardial Infarction
diagnoses.description: Commonly known as a heart attack, this condition results from the interruption of blood flow to a part of the heart, causing chest pain and potentially related to atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD)
diagnoses.description: A common circulatory problem in which narrowed arteries reduce blood flow to the limbs. While it primarily affects the legs, it is associated with atherosclerosis and could accompany symptoms like chest pain if the heart is also affected.

diagnoses.name: Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC) of the Oral Cavity
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in the squamous cells of the oral cavity. Leukoplakia can be a precursor lesion to this type of cancer. Symptoms may not directly include chest pain or hyperactivity but can be correlated in advanced disease stages through systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Cancer that begins in the lymphatic system. It can cause lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes) and, depending on the location and spread, might contribute to systemic symptoms including chest discomfort.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often called mono, this infectious disease typically caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) can result in significant lymphadenopathy, fever, and sore throat. Though less common, it can affect the heart or liver, potentially leading to chest pain or systemic hyperactivity symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Pulmonary Hypertension
diagnoses.description: A type of high blood pressure that affects the arteries in the lungs and the right side of the heart. It may lead to chest pain among other symptoms and could have indirect associations with conditions like atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Heart Failure
diagnoses.description: A chronic, progressive condition in which the heart muscle is unable to pump enough blood to meet the body's needs for blood and oxygen. Can manifest as chest pain and is often associated with atherosclerosis and other conditions leading to compromised cardiac function.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis (TB)
diagnoses.description: A potentially serious infectious bacterial disease that mainly affects the lungs but can also affect lymph nodes, leading to lymphadenopathy, and potentially causing chest pain as a symptom.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) infection and its advanced stage, Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS), can cause generalized lymphadenopathy. Associations with conditions like leukoplakia, due to immune suppression, can be observed, indirect connections to the other symptoms through systemic effects might be present.

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue, sleep abnormalities, and pain that's worsened by exertion. Monocytosis could be incidental or related to an ongoing infection or immune response.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life. Can manifest physically with symptoms like insomnia, non-restorative sleep, and changes in appetite which could hypothetically lead to dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: This condition can cause neurological symptoms (such as presyncope), psychiatric symptoms, hematological abnormalities (like monocytosis), and could theoretically impair taste (dysgeusia) and sleep patterns.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: Characterized by excessive worry or fear. Anxiety can cause physical symptoms like presyncope and lead to sleep disturbances including insomnia and non-restorative sleep.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that originates in certain blood-forming cells of the bone marrow. It often shows elevated white blood cells, including monocytes (monocytosis), and can cause systemic symptoms like fatigue and weight loss.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. Dysgeusia, insomnia, and non-restorative sleep are common in fibromyalgia patients.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Symptoms can include fatigue, elevated blood lipid levels, and may lead to sleep disturbances and mood swings.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving your central nervous system. It can cause symptoms like fatigue, numbness or weakness in one or more limbs, and could potentially lead to issues like dysgeusia due to lesions in the brain.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: This type of anemia occurs when the body doesn't have enough iron to produce hemoglobin. Symptoms can include tiredness, pale skin, and may influence sleep quality and mood.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Also known as mono, this is an infectious disease typically caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). It can cause fatigue, fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes, potentially leading to monocytosis.

diagnoses: Hearing impairment due to ototoxic medication

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones. Hypothyroidism may not cause noticeable symptoms in the early stages, but over time, untreated hypothyroidism can cause a number of health problems, such as obesity, joint pain, infertility, and heart disease.

diagnoses.name: Turner Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A chromosomal disorder affecting females where one of the X chromosomes is missing or partially missing, which can cause delayed puberty and is often associated with short stature and infertility.

diagnoses.name: Constitutional Growth Delay
diagnoses.description: A common temporary delay in the skeletal growth and thus height of a child with no other physical abnormalities causing the delay. Children with this diagnosis are often referred to as 'late bloomers.'

diagnoses.name: Autism Spectrum Disorder
diagnoses.description: A developmental disorder that affects communication and behavior, and can influence a child's ability to interact socially and might contribute to symptoms such as attention deficits.

diagnoses.name: Klinefelter Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic condition affecting males, and is caused by an extra X chromosome. Symptoms can include delayed puberty and social and learning difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Juvenile Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Hypothyroidism specifically in children and adolescents, leading to delayed puberty, poor growth, and symptoms such as constipation and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Prader-Willi Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder due to loss of function of specific genes. Early symptoms may include poor muscle tone, low levels of sex hormones, and a constant feeling of hunger leading to obesity.

diagnoses.name: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.description: A brain disorder marked by an ongoing pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity that interferes with functioning or development.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Constipation
diagnoses.description: A common condition that affects people of all ages, defined by having fewer than three bowel movements weekly or difficult bowel movements. While not a diagnosis on its own, when combined with other symptoms, it can indicate an underlying condition.

diagnoses.name: Blepharospasm
diagnoses.description: A condition causing involuntary tight closure of the eyelid(s), included here as a specific symptom but not an underlying diagnosis. It may occur due to neurological conditions, external irritants, or as part of a wider syndrome involving hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a lack of healthy red blood cells, which can cause pallor and palpitations due to inadequate oxygen transport to the body's tissues.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic response causing itchy, watery eyes, sneezing, and other similar symptoms, which may include Hypersensitivity reactions and coryza.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder that can lead to gastroparesis, a condition in which the stomach cannot empty itself of food in a normal fashion, and may also cause symptoms like pallor.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: An overactive thyroid gland which can cause palpitations, hypersensitivity reactions, and sometimes coryza due to the overall hyperactivity of the body's metabolism.

diagnoses.name: Heart Failure
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition where the heart does not pump blood as well as it should, leading to symptoms such as palpitations and pallor.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by the inappropriate release of mast cell mediators, causing symptoms such as Hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.description: A rare tumor of the adrenal gland tissue, causing excess production of adrenaline and noradrenaline, which can lead to palpitations and pallor.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency
diagnoses.description: The most common cause of anemia, characterized by a lack of iron, which leads to pallor, among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A digestive disorder that affects the lower esophageal sphincter, leading to possible gastroparesis, although more commonly causing heartburn and regurgitation.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest. It can be associated with pallor and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Allergic Rhinitis with associated Gastrointestinal Manifestations
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD), such as Crohn's Disease or Ulcerative Colitis
Vasovagal Syncope (as a reaction to the stress of severe gastrointestinal symptoms)

diagnoses.name: Allergic reaction
diagnoses.description: An immune system response to a foreign substance that's not typically harmful to your body. These substances are called allergens. They can include certain foods, pollen, or pet dander. The immune response can cause symptoms like angioedema, pruritis, and gastrointestinal upset.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur rapidly. It can cause angioedema, abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and more severe symptoms like difficulty breathing.

diagnoses.name: Food intolerance
diagnoses.description: Difficulty digesting certain foods and having an unpleasant physical reaction to them. It can cause symptoms such as diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and pruritis.

diagnoses.name: Food allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction that occurs soon after eating a certain food. Symptoms can include diarrhea, abdominal cramps, angioedema, and pruritis.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)
diagnoses.description: An umbrella term for disorders that involve chronic inflammation of your digestive tract, such as Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. Symptoms include diarrhea and abdominal cramps.

diagnoses.name: Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: A common disorder that affects the large intestine, causing symptoms like abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and abdominal pain.

diagnoses.name: Mast cell activation syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by a proliferation of mast cells or abnormal release of these cells' chemicals, leading to severe allergic symptoms, including angioedema, pruritis, and gastrointestinal symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition causing repeated episodes of severe swelling. The most common areas of the body to develop swelling are the limbs, face, intestinal tract, and airway.

diagnoses.name: Eosinophilic gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: A rare digestive disorder where eosinophils, a type of white blood cell, build up in the digestive tract and blood, causing abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and possibly angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Drug reaction
diagnoses.description: An adverse reaction or side effect to a medication. Symptoms can include rash, diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and angioedema. Pruritis and conjunctival injections can also be observed, depending on the drug involved.

diagnoses: Common cold with secondary bacterial infection
Allergic Rhinitis with a secondary infection
Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) with a concurrent upper respiratory tract infection
Viral hemorrhagic fevers (e.g., Ebola, Dengue Fever)
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) exacerbation due to allergy

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Strokes may cause symptoms such as paralysis, speech difficulties, and sensory disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a chronic autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system, leading to a wide range of symptoms including muscle weakness, numbness, difficulty with coordination and balance, and problems with speech (dysarthria) and hearing.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Depending on its location, it can cause a wide variety of symptoms including weakness, difficulty speaking (aphasia), sensory problems, and hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines can sometimes be preceded or accompanied by sensory warning signs (aura), including visual disturbances, numbness, weakness, and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. TIA doesn’t cause permanent damage and can manifest with symptoms such as sudden weakness, numbness, speech problems, and confusion.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is the inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. It can lead to a wide array of symptoms, including fever, headache, stiff neck, aversion to light, weakness, and in severe cases, changes in mental status, seizures, speech, and hearing problems.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: Peripheral neuropathy results from damage to the peripheral nerves and causes weakness, numbness and pain, typically in the hands and feet. It can also affect other areas and body functions including digestion, urination, and circulation.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: Acoustic neuroma is a noncancerous and usually slow-growing tumor that develops on the main nerve leading from the inner ear to the brain. Symptoms can include hearing loss, ringing in the ear, dizziness, and balance problems.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: ALS, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, is a progressive neurological disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord, causing loss of muscle control. ALS can present with symptoms such as weakness, muscle cramps, difficulty speaking, and swallowing.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: Lyme disease is a bacterial infection transmitted through tick bites. Early symptoms include fever, headache, fatigue, and a characteristic skin rash. If untreated, infection can spread to joints, the heart, and the nervous system, leading to symptoms including weakness, numbness, and problems with speech and hearing.
A medical condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. It can lead to symptoms like aphasia, ataxia, and dysarthria.
A type of headache that is often preceded or accompanied by sensory warning signs such as scintillations, scotomas, and sometimes speech or language issues.
A chronic illness involving your central nervous system. It can cause symptoms like ataxia, dysarthria, and in some cases visual disturbances like scotomas.
An abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause symptoms depending on the tumor's location, such as aphasia if it affects language centers, or ataxia for tumors impacting coordination.
Often called a mini-stroke, it's a brief period of symptoms similar to those you'd experience in a stroke, such as aphasia and ataxia.

A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Some rare forms can cause aphasia and ataxia.
Bleeding within the brain, which can lead to a rapid loss of brain function with symptoms such as aphasia, ataxia, and dysarthria depending on the hemorrhage location.
A condition resulting from restricted blood flow to the back part of the brain, which can lead to symptoms like ataxia, dysarthria, and visual disturbances.
A type of tumor that occurs in the brain and spinal cord, gliomas can cause neurological symptoms varying by their location, potentially including aphasia, ataxia, and dysarthria.
A rare, progressive cerebrovascular disorder caused by blocked arteries at the base of the brain. The main symptoms include stroke, aphasia, and sometimes ataxia.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, Microscopic Polyangiitis)

diagnoses.name: Lupus erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by symptoms like skin rash, joint pain, and fatigue. Lupus can cause panniculitis, postinflammatory dyspigmentation, arthropathy, synovitis, and telangiectasias among other manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rash. It's one of a group of muscle diseases that involve muscle inflammation and weakness. The skin rash can lead to postinflammatory dyspigmentation and telangiectasias.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disorder that affects joints, causing swelling, pain, and potential joint deformity. Arthropathy and synovitis are primary features; it can also present with skin changes such as rheumatoid nodules and vasculitis, potentially affecting the skin's appearance.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.description: A group of autoimmune diseases that cause the skin and connective tissues to harden and tighten. Telangiectasias are a common manifestation, and it can also present with arthropathy and synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.description: A skin disease that causes red, itchy scaly patches, most commonly on the knees, elbows, trunk, and scalp. Psoriasis can lead to psoriatic arthritis, a related condition that affects joints and may present with synovitis and arthropathy.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. The disease can lead to numerous symptoms, including skin rashes, arthritis, and sores in the mouth and genitals. It might also cause postinflammatory dyspigmentation.

diagnoses.name: Granuloma annulare
diagnoses.description: A chronic skin condition that causes raised, reddish or skin-colored bumps usually forming ring patterns. It might be associated with mild joint pain or discomfort (arthropathy).

diagnoses.name: Erythema nodosum
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition characterized by inflammation of the fat cells under the skin, resulting in tender red nodules or lumps that are usually seen on the shins. It can be associated with joint pain and other symptoms like fever and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. Skin lesions, arthropathy, and less commonly, erythema nodosum, which can lead to postinflammatory pigmentation changes, may occur.

A rare autoimmune disorder that exhibits features of three other connective tissue diseases — lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, leading to a variety of symptoms across the body, including skin changes, arthropathy, synovitis, and vascular abnormalities like telangiectasias.

diagnoses: Epilepsy (in the context of systemic disease and CNS involvement)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the skin, joints, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that primarily affects joints but can also cause systemic issues, including anemia and rarely, seizures.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder that causes blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, leading to numerous symptoms including oral ulcers, arthritis, and occasionally, central nervous system involvement that may cause seizures.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the glands that produce moisture, sometimes resulting in systemic complications, including joint pain and rare nervous system involvement.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that exhibits features of several connective tissue diseases, including lupus, polymyositis, and scleroderma, and can cause a wide range of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that cause blood vessel inflammation, leading to a range of symptoms depending on the organs affected, potentially including hemolytic anemia and seizures.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenia, and occasionally associated with other autoimmune conditions.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that increases the risk of blood clots. It can lead to various systemic manifestations including a risk of hemolytic anemia and neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
diagnoses.description: Include Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. Can cause systemic symptoms including joint pain (arthropathy), and less commonly, other symptoms listed due to systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Lupus-like Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition that presents with symptoms similar to systemic lupus erythematosus but does not meet all the criteria for a diagnosis of SLE.

diagnoses: Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Felty's Syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
